facts.text: Appellant was occupying premises as tenant; landlady filed H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967 seeking eviction on ground of bona fide requirement for own occupation.
Suit premises No. 64, Lloyds Road, Royapettah, Madras-14 advertised for sale; appellant purchased it on October 23, 1967, per registered document No. 1633 of 1967.
Respondent was tenant under previous owner; after purchase, attorned to appellant and paid rent.
Eviction order passed against appellant in H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967 on January 27, 1968; time given till January 27, 1969 to vacate.

Appellant issued two notices to respondent on January 27, 1968 under section 106 of Transfer of Property Act terminating tenancy, calling for vacant possession by February 29, 1968; notices referred to purchase for own occupation and eviction order against appellant.

Appellant filed H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 in Court of Small Causes, Madras under section 10(3)(a)(i) of Madras Buildings Lease Rent Control Act, 1960 for eviction on ground of bona fide requirement for own occupation; stated no other house in Madras.

Respondent filed counter-affidavit July 19, 1968 denying tenancy (claimed Ms. R.M. Seshadri firm as tenant); additional counter January 14, 1969 denying bona fides, challenging eviction order against appellant, purchase validity, improvements by tenant, notice validity.

Enquiry commenced January 16, 1969; appellant examined as PW1 till February 20, 1969; deposed to tenancy history, purchase for occupation, respondent's attornment, notices; filed 45 exhibits including certified copy of eviction order (Ex P-45).
On March 31, 1969, parties filed memo of compromise: respondent withdraws defence, submits to unconditional eviction decree, time till June 5, 1969 to vacate; executable as decree.
Court of Small Causes passed order on March 31, 1969: 'Compromise memo filed and recorded. By consent eviction is ordered granting time to vacate till 5-6-1969. No costs.' Incorporated terms.
Appellant paid Rs. 20,000 to respondent on March 31, 1969 towards repairs/improvements.
Respondent wrote letter on March 31, 1969 undertaking to vacate by June 5, 1969; acknowledged Rs. 20,000; agreed to refund if fails, pay Rs. 10,000 damages; liberty to execute without notice.
Respondent's son filed suit in City Civil Court declaring appellant's purchase void; obtained interim injunction against execution; suit dismissed December 12, 1969 with costs to appellant.
Appellant filed Execution Petition No. 953 of 1969 in City Civil Court.
Respondent filed E.A. No. 1314 of 1969 objecting execution: decree nullity as contravenes sec 10, no independent satisfaction of bona fides.
City Civil Judge by order March 18, 1970 overruled objections, dismissed E.A., time till April 20, 1970 to vacate.
Respondent filed C.R.P. No. 797 of 1970 in Madras High Court; allowed September 15, 1970, holding eviction order nullity.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order dated March 31, 1969 passed by Court of Small Causes, Madras in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directing eviction of respondent-tenant is a nullity and not executable, as Rent Controller did not independently satisfy itself of landlord's bona fide requirement under section 10(3)(a)(i) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant pleaded and proved bona fide requirement via evidence (PW1, 45 exhibits); respondent withdrew defence unconditionally after evidence, accepting claim; court satisfied as stage reached to apply mind.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10(3)(a)(i) Madras Buildings Lease Rent Control Act, 1960

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court misunderstood SC precedents; decree not solely on compromise.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bahadur Singh, Kaushalya Devi, Ferozi Lal Jain (distinguished)

respondent_arguments.text: Decree passed exclusively on compromise; no indication Rent Controller applied mind or satisfied itself of bona fide requirement; mandatory under sec 10; executing court cannot enquire into satisfaction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10 Madras Buildings Lease Rent Control Act, 1960; Bahadur Singh, Kaushalya Devi, Ferozi Lal Jain

respondent_arguments.text: Disputed title, notice validity; remand needed.

court_reasoning.text: Stage reached where Controller called to apply mind (evidence led, no cross-exam); respondent's unconditional withdrawal of defence after evidence amounts to admission of bona fide requirement; court can infer satisfaction from materials/record.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenant's withdrawal post-evidence shows acceptance of landlord's statutory ground.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes SC precedents: unlike those, here material existed, tenant impliedly admitted; consent order valid if jurisdictional fact (bona fide need) shown to exist.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Satisfaction need not be expressly stated if inferable; no need for further enquiry on admission.

court_reasoning.text: Executing court can consider if decree void; no elaborate enquiry issue as materials available; withdrawn defences (title, notice) not revive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rent Controller as quasi-judicial can act on compromise if ground pleaded and stage reached.

court_reasoning.text: Separate opinion: No objection to compromise consenting to eviction if on statutory ground; controller satisfaction can be on admission/evidence like civil court; criticises over-formalism.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tenant not to be treated as minor; compromise valid per Order 23 Rule 3 CPC principles.

holdings.text: Eviction order dated March 31, 1969 not nullity; executable as Controller satisfied of bona fide requirement inferable from proceedings/evidence/admission via compromise.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bahadur Singh & Anr. v. Muni Subrat Dass & Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree on award without landlord party or court satisfaction void; unlike here where evidence led.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kaushalya Devi & Ors. v. Shri K.L. Bansal
precedents_cited.relevance: Compromise decree without indicated statutory ground void; here grounds evidenced.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ferozi Lal Jain v. Man Mal & Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: No court mind application to subletting; here stage reached with materials.

precedents_cited.case_name: Remon v. City of London Real Property Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Court may act on tenant admission without full hearing.
Consent order valid if tenant effectively admits statutory ground.
No need to investigate admitted facts supporting statutory ground.
Court can act on implied admission post-representation/evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babu Ram Sharma v. Pal Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Compromise decree valid if on pleaded statutory ground like non-payment.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Embargo on eviction except per section; landlord may evict residential building for own occupation if bona fide and no other house; Controller must be satisfied.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Objections to execution; compromise decrees; no similar protection for tenants as minors.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Madras High Court judgment/order dated September 15, 1970 set aside; City Civil Court order dated March 18, 1970 restored; costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "The short question that arises for consideration in this appeal... is whether the order dated March 31, 1969... is a nullity and as such not executable."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "His withdrawal of the defence, after the plaintiff had given evidence and filed exhibits in support of his plea, clearly shows that he accepted as true the claim of the landlord."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to inferring admission and court satisfaction.

key_quotes.text: "Satisfaction of the Court... need not be by the manifestation borne out by a judicial finding. If at some stage the Court was called upon to apply its mind... it is possible to postulate that the Court was satisfied."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle distinguishing precedents; validates consent order.

key_quotes.text: "I think, therefore, the time has come when a hard look must be taken on this point and it should be held that there is no objection to a compromise consenting to an order of eviction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Separate opinion advocating pragmatic approach to compromises.
